journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Educational and Behavioral Statistics

title-group.article-title: Comparing Regression Coefficients Between Nested Linear Models for Clustered Data With Generalized Estimating Equations

bio.title: Authors
bio.p: JUN YAN is an associate professor, Department of Statistics, University of Connecticut, 215 Glenbrook Rd. U-4120, Storrs, CT 06269; email: jun.yan@uconn.edu. He is a Research Fellow at the Institute for Public Health Research, University of Connecticut Health Center. His research interests are dynamic survival models, multivariate dependence, spatial statistics, and statistical computing.

ROBERT H. ASELTINE, JR., is a director of the Institute for Public Health Research, Deputy Director of the Center for Public Health and Health Policy, and is a Professor in the Division of Behavioral Sciences and Community Health at the University of Connecticut Health Center, 263 Farmington Avenue, MC 3910, Farmington, CT 06030; email: aseltine@uchc.edu. He is a medical sociologist with expertise in quantitative research methods and statistics, particularly in designing large-scale population surveys and multisite, community-based evaluations of preventive interventions.

OFER HAREL is an associate professor, Department of Statistics, University of Connecticut, 215 Glenbrook Rd. U-4120, Storrs, CT 06269; email: ofer.harel@uconn.edu. He is a Principal Investigator, the Center for Health, Intervention, and Prevention, University of Connecticut. His research interests focus on the analysis of incomplete data and confidentiality issues related to Alzheimers, diabetes, nutrition, HIV/AIDS, and alcohol and drug abuse prevention.

abstract.p: Comparing regression coefficients between models when one model is nested within another is of great practical interest when two explanations of a given phenomenon are specified as linear models. The statistical problem is whether the coefficients associated with a given set of covariates change significantly when other covariates are added into the model as controls. Methods for such comparison exist for independent data but do not apply when data are clustered such as longitudinal or familial data. Under the framework of generalized estimating equations, the authors develop statistical methods for such comparison. The properties of the proposed estimator of the difference in regression coefficients between two models are studied asymptotically and for finite samples through simulation. Application of the method to data on changes in depression mood from adolescence through young adulthood reveals that the effect of age after controlling for work status and marital status, although still significant, is largely reduced.

body.p: Comparing the coefficients of the same set of covariates between models when one model is nested within another is widely used in medical research (e.g., Fiscella & Franks, 2010), public health (e.g., Pande, Ross-Degnan, Zaslavsky, & Salomon, 2011), and social science (e.g., Sampson, Raudenbush, & Earls, 1997). Such comparison arises when two explanations of a given phenomenon are specified as linear models, and researchers are interested in whether the coefficients associated with a given set of covariates change significantly when additional covariates are added into the model. Is the regression relationship between the response and a covariate of interest stable across two specifications? Or, does “controlling” for additional covariates suppress or enhance the relationship between the response and the covariate? Statistical methods for such comparison have been developed with independently observed response variables conditioned on covariates in linear and generalized linear models (Clogg, Petkova, & Haritou, 1995b; Allison, 1995). These methods have been widely used by practitioners because the standard errors of the estimated change in coefficients are simple calculations based on quantities from routine statistical software output.

When response variables are dependent, the methods of Clogg, Petkova, and Haritou (1995b) are not valid, which is often the case when observations are clustered within some larger unit (e.g., students within schools, repeated measures from the same subjects). The availability of clustered data in behavioral and medical research has increased of late due to the advent of data collection technologies, such as Interactive Voice Response systems (e.g., Abu-Hasaballah, James, & Aseltine, 2007) that allow for the efficient collection of longitudinal data with observations nested within individuals, as well as the development of statistical packages that have made more sophisticated growth modeling techniques accessible to nonstatisticians (e.g., Bryk, Raudenbush, & Congdon, 1996, for hierarchical data modeling with the hierarchical linear modeling software). Such data structures are common in studies seeking to identify the processes through which a treatment or intervention impacts study participants over time but require appropriate statistical tests to assess changes in coefficients when explanatory measures are introduced into the model. Clustered data are usually handled with the assumption of between-cluster independence and within-cluster dependence. Because of the within-cluster dependence, a naive application of Clogg et al. (1995b) leads to underestimation of the variation in the coefficient changes. A valid statistical method for comparing regression coefficients between nested models for clustered data is much needed in practice but challenging due to the need to account for within-cluster dependence. This is the topic of our investigation.

For nonlinear models, even when the additional covariates are independent of the existing ones, their presence changes the coefficient estimates of the existing covariates. Under the assumption that the full model is the true model, the omitted variables in the reduced model leads to bigger variation or overdispersion (Allison, 1999; Williams, 2009). The coefficient estimates of the existing covariates are attenuated toward zero; the bigger the variance of the omitted variables, the higher degree of the attenuation. This issue arises from nonlinear models and is not fully studied for nonclustered data in Clogg et al. (1995b). The interpretation of the difference in covariate coefficients between nested nonlinear models remains to be clearly defined. Therefore, we focus on coefficient comparison between linear models.

As a motivating example, consider a recent longitudinal study of age-related changes in depressed mood from adolescence through young adulthood with high school students in the greater Boston metropolitan area (Gore & Aseltine, 2003). Evidence suggests that the transition to adulthood may be a time of improved mental health for U.S. adolescents as a result of beneficial changes in social roles and relationships during that period (Aseltine & Gore, 2005; Masten et al., 2004). To demonstrate this pattern of effects, we would want to estimate two nested models using data from a prospective study of adolescents/young adults, first regressing depressed mood on age, and subsequently adding indicators of changes in prominent social roles (e.g., work status and marital status) to the model as covariates. A statistically significant difference in the coefficients from these nested models would be an indication that decreases in depressed mood with increasing age could be partially explained by the measures of changes in work and relationship status included in the full model. A significant effect of age in the full model would suggest that there are still age-related differences in depression after accounting for these prominent social roles.

Generalized estimating equations (GEEs) are a popular method for marginal modeling of clustered data (Liang & Zeger, 1986). This approach only specifies the marginal mean of the multivariate response without fully specifying a multivariate distribution. Instead of modeling the nuisance within-cluster dependence, the method uses working correlation models which lead to consistent and potentially efficient estimators of the regression coefficients in the mean model. The variances of the coefficient estimates are consistently estimated with a “sandwich” estimator. The closer the working correlation approximates the true correlation, the higher the efficiency. The interpretation of the regression coefficients in GEE models is population average as opposed to cluster specific (e.g., Hardin & Hilbe, 2003). Implementations of GEE are available in standard statistical software. We approach the comparison of coefficients between linear models for clustered data in the general framework of GEE.

The rest of the article is organized as follows. We first set up the problem and define the target quantities of the statistical inference procedures. The estimator of the target quantities and its asymptotic properties are presented next. Finite-sample performance of the proposed estimator is assessed in a large-scale simulation study. An analysis of the data on adolescent depression, made possible by the proposed method, illustrates the utility of the method. A discussion concludes.

sec.title: Comparing Coefficients With GEE
sec.p:
Consider a linear regression setting for clustered data. Let Yi be a ki × 1 response vector, Xi be a ki × p covariate matrix, and Zi be a ki × q covariate matrix, where ki is the size of cluster i. Further, Xi and Zi do not share columns. The observed data are n independent and identically distributed copies:
{

. With GEE, only the conditional mean of Yi , as opposed to the whole density of Yi , is specified through a known link function g conditioning on covariate information. For linear models, link g is the identity link.

The quantities of interest are the changes in the coefficients of Xi in predicting the mean of Yi with and without Zi in the conditioning set. In particular, consider a reduced model M 0:
1

where β and b are p × 1 coefficient vectors of Xi with and without Zi , respectively, in the model, and γ is a q × 1 coefficient vector of Zi . We are interested in the difference in the regression coefficient of Xi between model M 1 and model M 0: δ = β - b. The null hypothesis H 0: δ = 0 is of scientific interest.

Before any discussion of statistical inferences about δ, we need to clarify its interpretation. Clogg et al. (1995b) assumed that model M 1 is the true data-generating model, and model M 0 is a misspecified model. Under model M 1, β is well defined. For nonclustered data, b is the pseudo-true value which minimizes the Kullback–Leibler divergence in model M 0. For clustered data under the GEE framework, however, as the joint distribution is not fully specified, the Kullback–Leibler divergence is no longer defined. The interpretation of δ depends on how we define b, the coefficient of Xi in the misspecified, reduced model M 0 under the assumption that the true model is the full model M 1. We will come back to this issue after presenting the GEE for both models.

Two important special cases are (a) all covariates are cluster-level covariates (all elements of Σt are ones) and (b) all covariates are individual-level covariates and components in each covariate vector are independent across individuals (Σt is the identity matrix). sec.title: Finite-Sample Performance
sec.p:
We investigate the finite-sample performance of the estimators and the Wald test in a simulation study mimicking a longitudinal setting. Let n be the number of subjects and each subject has ki = 3 measures. For subject i, our covariates Xi has two columns and the additional covariate Zi has only one column; that is, we have p = 3 (including an intercept) and q = 1. The covariates are generated from a multivariate normal distribution with standard margins and two possible covariance structure
Ξ 1
=
1.00
0.25
0.30
0.25
1.00
0.45
0.30
0.45
1.00
a n d
Ξ 2
=
1.00
0.25
0.00
0.25
1.00
0.00
0.00
0.00
1.00
.

The response variable given covariates is multivariate normal. Within each subject, two correlation structures are considered: exchangeable (EX) and autoregressive of order 1 (AR1). For each correlation structure, two levels of correlation level ρ are used: .4 and .8, representing moderate and strong within cluster dependence. The data are generated from model M 1 with covariate coefficients θ 0 = (1,1, - 1,1) or (1,1, - 1,0).

Three scenarios of δ were setup. In scenario a, θ 0 = (1,1, - 1,1) and the covariance matrix of (X 1, X 2, Z 1) is Ξ 1, resulting a nonzero δ 0. In Scenario b, θ 0 = (1,1, - 1,0) and the covariance matrix of (X 1, X 2, Z 1) is Ξ 1, resulting δ 0 = (0,0,0). In Scenario c, θ 0 = (1,1, - 1,1) and the covariance matrix of (X 1, X 2, Z 1) is Ξ 2, resulting δ 0 = (0,0,0).

Three types of covariate structures were considered: cluster level, individual level, and mixed level. For the cluster-level structure, each covariate is the same within cluster. For the individual-level structure, each covariate varies independently within cluster. For the mixed-level structure, the first covariate in X is at the cluster level while the second covariate in X and Z are at the individual level. Under all structures, the covariate matrix of the three covariates is maintained at Ξ 1 or Ξ 2.

The simulation setup also illustrates that the true value of δ depends on the covariance structure of
V e c h
( X , Z )
, true value γ 0, and the within-cluster correlation structure of the response Y. The true values δ 0 under each configuration are summarized in Table 1. It is observed that the true values of δ are not always the same, although very close for each dependence level ρ. In fact, in Scenario a with mixed-level covariates, as ρ decreases toward zero, the values of δ 0 go to (0,0.2,0.4). The value of δ 0 in Scenario a with cluster-level covariates does not depend on the correlation structure because
C o v
{
V e c h
(
X i
,
Z i
) }
is separable in this case. This is not necessarily true in Scenario a with individual-level covariates, although in our simulation it is true because
C o v
{
V e c h
(
X i
,
Z i
) }
is separable due to that fact Ξ 1 or Ξ 2 remains the same for all time points.

caption.p: True Values of δ Under Different Simulation Setups

fn.p: Note: AR1 = autoregressive of order 1; EX = exchangeable.

sec.p: For each configuration, we generated 1,000 data sets. Both models M 0 and M 1 were fit, and estimates of δ and standard errors were obtained. Biases of the estimates were obtained by taking the difference between the average of the estimates and the true values δ 0 in Table 1. As our interest lies in the change of coefficients in the two covariates in X, we discarded inferences about the intercept. The results are summarized in Tables 2 through 4 for cluster-level, individual-level, and mixed-level covariate structures, respectively.

caption.p: Summaries of Inferences About δ With Cluster-Level Covariates

fn.p: Note: AR1 = autoregressive of order 1; EX = exchangeable. Bias is 1,000 times of the absolute bias. SD is the standard deviation of the estimates. ASE is the average of the estimated standard errors. COV is the empirical coverage percentage of 95% confidence interval.

caption.p: Summaries of Inferences About δ With Individual-Level Covariates

fn.p: Note: EX = exchangeable; AR1 = autoregressive of order 1. Bias is 1,000 times of the absolute bias. SD is the standard deviation of the estimates. ASE is the average of the estimated standard errors. COV is the empirical coverage percentage of 95% confidence interval.

caption.p: Summaries of Inferences About δ With Mixed-Level Covariates

fn.p: Note: AR1 = autoregressive of order 1; EX = exchangeable. Bias is 1,000 times of the absolute bias. SD is the standard deviation of the estimates. ASE is the average of the estimated standard errors. COV is the empirical coverage percentage of 95% confidence interval.

sec.p: In addition to bias, we report the empirical standard deviation of the estimate (SD), the average of the estimated standard errors (ASE), and the empirical coverage percentage of 95% confidence intervals. The results suggest that our point estimator is virtually unbiased. The close agreement between the SD and ASE, especially when the sample size is 400, suggests that the variance estimates provide a reasonably good measure of the variation in the estimator. Consequently, the empirical coverage percentages of 95% confidence intervals are very close to the nominal level.

To check the finite-sample performance of the Wald test for H 0 : δ1 = δ2 = 0, we plot the histograms of the test statistic from 1,000 replicates. As these plots are all similar, we present only the three scenarios with mixed-level covariate structure, AR1 correlation structure of responses within cluster, ρ = .4, and sample size n = 400. The three histograms are plotted in Figure 1. For Scenario a, the test statistics follow a noncentral chi-square distribution, which is very different from the null distribution, chi-square with 2 degrees of freedom. This suggests that the Wald test has substantial power. For Scenarios b and c, the test statistics asymptotically follow chi-square distributions with 2 and 1 degrees of freedom, respectively, because δ 0 = 0 for different reasons. The histograms of the observed statistics are overlaid with the densities of chi-square distribution with 2 and 1 degrees of freedom, respectively. The close agreement suggests that the null distribution is approximated well by the asymptotic distribution.

caption.p:
Histograms of test statistics from 1,000 replicates in three scenarios with mixed-level covariate structure, autoregressive of order 1 (AR1) correlation structure of responses within cluster,
\irho
= .4
, and sample size
n
= 400
. Left: Scenario a. Center: Scenario b. Right: Scenario c. The overlaid lines in the center and right panels are the densities of chi-square distribution with 2 and 1 degrees of freedom, respectively.

sec.title: Depression Data Analysis
sec.p:
To further demonstrate the application of this procedure, we provide an example from a recent longitudinal study of high school students. Six waves of longitudinal data were collected over a 12-year period from an initial sample of 1,208 high school students residing in three communities in the greater Boston metropolitan area. The response rate in the initial wave of the study was 77% and retention rates exceeded 85% in each successive interview. The number of observations are 1,036, 939, 900, 829, and 726, respectively, from waves 2 to 6 with a monotone dropout. Students ranged in age from 14 to 29 years of age over the six waves of data collection. Assuming missing completely at random, we conduct our analysis based on all the observed data. Depressive symptoms were measured using a modified version of the 20-item Center for Epidemiological Studies Depression (CES-D) scale (Kohout, Berkman, Evans, & Cornoni-Huntley, 1993; Radloff, 1977). This measure contains a subset of 11 CES-D items which ask how often in the past week the respondent felt the following ways: poor appetite, feeling depressed, feeling that everything is an effort, restless sleep, feeling lonely, feeling people were unfriendly, feeling sad, feeling that people disliked you, not being able to get going, feeling happy (reverse scored), and enjoying life (reverse scored). This smaller set of items was chosen on the basis of prior work (Ross & Mirowsky, 1984) and reflects the four-dimension factor structure that is seen to represent the major components of depressive symptomatology. The validity and reliability of the CES-D measure has been well established in a number of studies seeking to ascertain its psychometric properties and relationship to diagnostic assessments (Gotlib, Lewinsohn, & Seeley, 1995). The short version of this measure has excellent reliability and validity, with an internal consistency exceeding .8 in all study waves, and a correlation of .96 with the full 20-item version. Each item used a 4-point scale ranging from (1) less than one day to (4) 5–7 days. Also measured in each study wave were dummy variables for marital status (1 = married) and full time work status (1 = employed 35+ hours/week). Finally, age was an intervally scaled variable ranging from 14 to 29 and centered by the median age 18. The covariates have mixed-level structure because gender is at the cluster level while age, marital status, and full time work status are at the individual level. The association between age and depressive symptoms was studied in two models M 0 and M 1:
E [
C E S D
] =
b 0
+
b 1
F e m a l e
+
b 2
A g e

and
E [
C E S D
] =
β 0
+
β 1
F e m a l e
+

A g e

γ 1
W k f u l l
+
γ 2
M a r r i e d
.

The difference between the two models is that, in model M 1, students’ work (wkfull) and marital status (married) were added. Using an unstructured working correlation, we estimated coefficients of both models and the differences in the coefficients of gender and age, with results summarized in Table 5. Results from model M 0 indicate that increasing age was significantly associated with lower levels of depressive symptoms, controlling for students’ gender. In the context of depression research, the magnitude of the age effect is nontrivial; across the total age range represented in the sample the effect size for age is roughly half a standard deviation—14(−.166)/4.84—which is far greater than the typical impact of major life events (e.g., divorce, death of a loved one, etc.) on depressed mood of roughly a quarter to a third of an SD (Aseltine & Kessler, 1993; McLeod & Kessler, 1990). Results from model M 1 indicates that both full-time employment (
γ ˆ
1
= − 0.421
, with standard error .156) and becoming married (
γ ˆ
2
= − 1.044
, with standard error .226) were significantly associated with lower levels of depressive symptoms. The age coefficient in model M 1 was reduced by about 37% compared to its magnitude in M 0, although the effect remained highly significant. Using the proposed inference procedure described above, the difference between the age coefficients in models M 0 and M 1 was estimated to be −.062, with a standard error of .014, which is statistically different from zero. Thus, although the association of age with depressive symptoms remains significant in the full model, the statistically significant change in this coefficient from the reduced to the full model indicates that a substantial portion of the reduction in depression symptoms as youths aged could be attributed to changes in work and marital status during the adolescent to young adult periods.

caption.p: Summaries of Estimated Coefficients From Two Nested Models and Their Differences for the Depression Data

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Comparing coefficients between nested models is common practice in medical, public health, and social and behavioral research. The need for such comparisons arises when researchers are interested in determining whether the effect of one variable is spurious or caused by another variable, or when examining the process through which some treatment or intervention affects study participants. To date, an appropriate method for conducting such tests with clustered data has not been developed. To address this problem, we proposed a marginal method in the GEE framework and our inferences reduce to those of Clogg et al. (1995b) and Allison (1995) when the data are independent instead of clustered.

The procedure of comparing coefficients between nested models is related to some other procedures. The model misspecification test of Hausman (1978) has a similar form, but as Clogg et al. (1995b) pointed out, it assumes that the reduced model is true whereas we assume that the full model is true. Mediation analysis intends to explain the process or mechanism by which a predictor affects a response variable through a mediator variable (e.g., MacKinnon, Fairchild, & Fritz, 2007). Partial mediation requires that the difference in the coefficient of the predictor in the two models is significant and complete mediation further requires that the coefficient is insignificant in the full model. The difference in the coefficient of the predictor across two models is interpreted as the indirect effect of the predictor on the response, the difference between the total effect (coefficient in the reduced model) and the direct effect (coefficient in the full model; e.g., Raudenbush & Sampson, 1999). Nevertheless, unlike in causal inferences, we do not specify the causal ordering of the variables. The logic here posits one outcome variable with two competing explanations for this single outcome (Clogg et al., 1995b, p. 1265).

Although the indirect effect in the mediation literature appears to be the same target of inference as our δ 0, the methodology and assumptions are quite different from ours. For a single mediator Z, the indirect effect can be estimated by the product of the regression coefficient of Z on X and that of Y on X, adjusted for Z (e.g., MacKinnon, 2008). The method has been extended to the context of longitudinal data (Cole & Maxwell, 2003) and multilevel data (Krull & MacKinnon, 2001); see also MacKinnon (2008), chapters 8 and 9, and references therein. These methods specify a linear relationship between the mediator Z and covariates X, and often assumes that the error terms are normally distributed (e.g., Tofighi, MacKinnon, & Yoon, 2009). In contrast, our method specifies neither a linear model of X given Z nor the error distribution except mean zero. The method of Schluchter (2008) is closer to our method in spirit, specifying only the mean in full and reduced models. This work handles independent responses only, however, and GEE is just used as a vehicle to estimate the coefficient differences and their variance.

Results presented in this article show that the proposed method provides a valid inference procedure to compare coefficients between two nested models for clustered data. We studied the problem in a GEE setting, with mild assumptions on the conditional mean specification of the responses. Our estimator is asymptotically unbiased and consistent, with an asymptotically normal distribution. The asymptotic variance estimator provides good measure of variation for sample sizes as small as 100 in our simulation study. As an alternative with higher computing cost, bootstrap can always be used to estimate the variance and may even be preferred with small samples

Special routines are needed to implement the proposed estimator. Our method has been added into an open source R package geepack (Yan & Fine, 2004), which is publicly available at the Comprehensive R Archive Network (http://CRAN.R-project.org; R Development Core Team, 2011; see Halekoh, Højsgaard, and Yan, 2006 for an earlier introduction on general usage of the package). The derivation of the variance estimator relies on the asymptotic representations of the coefficient estimator under the assumption that the full model is the true model. For mixed-effect models, one could estimate the parameters in the reduced model by minimizing the Kullback–Leibler divergence. Based on the asymptotic representation of the estimator, the asymptotic properties of
δ ˆ
n
can be similarly derived. Further investigation is worthwhile in that direction.

The proposed method has its practical limitations. When observation times are very irregularly distributed across clusters, there may be very little information on correlations between specific pairs to estimate an unstructured working correlation reasonably well. A simple solution would be to use working independence. Another possible solution is to use a parsimonious autoregressive correlation structure with correlation
ρ
i j
= exp ( α
|
t i
−
t j
|
)
for two time points ti and tj , with parameter α. In our data analysis, we have assumed missing completely at random which allowed us to exclude missing observations. Combining our method with missing data methods will be reported in a separate manuscript.
